fullContent:
**TITLE:**
  
Chungha’s Pop‑Up Party in Gangnam – Why It’s the New “Tim Hortons” for K‑Pop Fans

**SUMMARY:**
  
Just in time for the long weekend, Chungha’s pop‑up event in Gangnam is the place to be.

Grab a ticket, sip some Korean iced coffee, and get a taste of Seoul’s nightlife that’ll make you feel like you’re back in Toronto’s Kensington Market.

If you’re still scrolling through Instagram looking for the next “must‑visit” spot in Seoul, let me drop a quick note about a pop‑up that’s got everyone talking – Chungha’s pop‑up event in Gangnam.

Think of it as the K‑pop equivalent of a Tim Hortons double‑double, but with a whole lot more sparkle. 

### # What’s the Buzz All About.

title: Pop Mart’s “Labubu’s Suspicious Convenience Store” Pops Up in Seongsu – It’s Like a Toronto Pop‑Up, but K‑Style, eh?
summary: A pop‑up from Pop Mart is in Seoul’s hip Seongsu district. Think blind‑box fun, quirky merch, and a vibe that’ll feel like a Toronto Distillery Dis...
fullContent:
Hey friends! 👋  
You know how we love a good pop‑up when we’re in Toronto? Maybe the “Mosaic” pop‑up at the Distillery District, or that one‑day “Kicks & Kicks” sneaker event in Vancouver.

Well, guess what? Pop Mart Korea just opened a brand‑new popup called 

**“Labubu’s Suspicious Convenience Store”**
 right in Seongsu‑dong, and it’s already getting the buzz that would make a Canadian college student say, “Whoa, that’s lit!”  

**What’s the deal?**
  
Pop Mart is the Canadian‑style blind‑box company that started in Shanghai and now sells those ultra‑collectible figures that pop up in malls, airports, and now—

**Seongsu**
—a district that’s basically the Seoul equivalent of Toronto’s Queen West or Vancouver’s Yaletown.

The “Labubu” line is a quirky brand that mixes K‑pop aesthetics with a “convenience store” theme, so you’ll find mini‑figures that look like they just stepped out of a 7‑Eleven in Seoul.

Think a little “Skechers” meets “Coca‑Cola” meets “Labyrinth.”  

**Where & When?**
  
- 

**Location:**
 1st Street, Seongsu‑dong, Seong‑dong-gu, Seoul (just a 5‑minute walk from Seongsu Station, Line 2).  
- 

**Hours:**
 10:00 am – 10:00 pm daily.  
- 

**Duration:**
 1st–15th of this month (so it’s a quick‑fire event, about two weeks).  

**Cost & Currency:**
  
- 

**Entry:**
 Free (no need to buy a ticket, just stroll in).  
- 

**Products:**
 Prices start at 

**10,000 KRW**
 (about 

**$10 CAD**
).

Most

title: Yo, Canadians, Your New Bed‑Shopping Spot in Seoul is a Must‑See!
summary: Sealy’s pop‑up in Seongsu‑dong is the perfect spot for a quick sleep‑check‑in. We’ll spill the tea on where, when, how much, and why it’s a cultura...
fullContent:
Hey there, fellow Canucks! 👋  
You know how we love a good double‑double at Tim‑Hortons and a cozy night in our toques? Well, I’ve found a new way to keep our sleep game strong while we’re living the Seoul dream.

Sealy Bed, the global mattress brand (yeah, the same one that makes the “sleep like a log” mattresses we’re used to back home), opened a pop‑up shop called 

**Sealy Atelier**
 in Seongsu‑dong.

If you’re studying at Seoul National University, doing your exchange at Yonsei, or just chilling in the Gangnam area, this is a spot you’ll want to hit up.  

### Why This Is a Big Deal for Us

First off, Sealy’s pop‑up is more than a retail space.

It’s a 

**mini‑experience**
—think design studio meets mattress showroom.

They’re showcasing their latest tech, like memory‑foam hybrids and ergonomic supports, all in a sleek, modern setting.

For Canadians who are used to the “comfort” of our Canadian mattresses (think 

**IKEA**
 or 

**Lululemon’s**
 own line), it’s a chance to see how Korean design blends with Western tech.

Plus, if you’re a student in Korea, you’ve probably been staying in a cramped dorm or a small apartment.

A good mattress can seriously change your study life.

Sealy’s pop‑up is a chance to test out a mattress in person (no online mystery).  

### Practical Info – Where, When, How Much

| Detail | Info |
|--------|------|
| 

**Location**
 | Seongsu‑dong, Seoul – right next to the 

**Seongsu‑Art Street**
 area (the “Brooklyn of Seoul”). |
| 

**Address**
 | 123 Seongsu‑dong, Seoul 140-123 (exact address is on the Sealy website). |
| 

**Hours**
 | Mon‑Fri: 10 am‑7 pm, Sat‑Sun: 11 am‑6 pm. |
| 

**Entry Fee**
 | Free! (Just bring a snack if you’re a bit hungry, because they have a small café corner). |
| 

**Price Range**
 | Mattresses start at 

**KRW 1.2 million**
 (~CAD 1,000).

They have financing options, so you can spread it out over 12 months. |
| 

**How to Get There**
 | Take the subway Line 2 to 

**Seongsu Station**
 (Exit 1).

It’s a 5‑minute walk to the pop‑up. |
| 

**Parking**
 | Limited street parking; best to use public transit. |

**Tip:**
 If you’re on a tight budget, check out the “Student Discount” they offer on Mondays if you show your university ID.

It can shave off about 10% off the price.  

### Insider Tips: What Locals Know

1. 

**Test the “Sleep‑On‑Me” Feature**
 – Sealy has a “sleep‑on‑me” test bed where you can lie down for 5 minutes.

This is great for seeing how the mattress feels under your own weight.  
2. 

**Talk to the Staff**
 – They’re fluent in English and Korean.

Ask about the 

**“Sealy Smart Sleep”**
 line, which tracks your sleep patterns and syncs with an app.  
3. 

**Grab a Free Sample Pillow**
 – When you test a mattress, they’ll give you a free pillow (worth about CAD 20).  
4. 

**Check Out the Design Studio**
 – The pop‑up has a small gallery showcasing Korean designers’ work on mattress aesthetics.

It’s a cool visual treat if you’re into interior design.  
5. 

**Take a Photo for the ‘Gram**
 – The pop‑up has a dedicated photo booth with a backdrop that looks like a cozy bedroom.

Use the hashtag 

**#SealySeongsu**
 and you might get featured on Sealy’s Instagram.  

### Canadian Connection: How This Relates to Us

Think of Sealy Atelier as a cross‑border collaboration between our beloved comfort and Korea’s cutting‑edge design.

It’s kind of like how we love a good 

**Tim‑Hortons double‑double**
 but also appreciate the artistry of a 

**Nanaimo bar**
.

The pop‑up is a reminder that comfort can be both functional and artistic.

If you’re a Canadian student at the 

**University of Toronto**
 or 

**McGill**
, you’re used to the idea that a good night’s sleep is essential for learning.

Sealy’s pop‑up gives you a chance to invest in that sleep, even if you’re only staying in Korea for a semester.  

### Action: What You Should Do

1. 

**Plan a Visit**
 – Drop by on a weekday after classes or on the weekend if you’re free.  
2. **Book a

title: Hey, Canada! 🌎🍁 Check Out This Kakao Pay Popup in Seoul – It’s Like a Maple‑Syrup‑Infused Hangout
summary: Kakao Pay’s new “Together for a Long Time” popup in Seoul’s Seongsu district is the ultimate spot for Canadians craving a taste of Korean tech‑savv...
fullContent:
Hey there, fellow Canucks! 👋  
You know how we love a good pop‑up café in the Village or a seasonal pop‑up market in Vancouver? Well, Seoul’s got a brand‑new one that’s making waves: Kakao Pay’s “Together for a Long Time” popup at Torotoro Seongsu.

It’s a blend of tech, food, and community vibes that feels oddly familiar to us, yet totally Korean.

Let me break it down for you.

### # What’s the Deal?

Kakao Pay, the Korean equivalent of our UnionPay or even PayPal, launched this popup in the trendy Seongsu‑dong neighborhood – Seoul’s answer to Brooklyn or the Annex.

The concept? A temporary space where people can experience the future of payments, try out new food concepts, and just hang out in a vibe that feels like a community center for the digital age.

Think of it as a cross between a tech expo, a pop‑up market, and a chill café, all wrapped into one.

The popup opened on 

**April 15th**
 and runs 

**until June 30th**
 (so we’re talking a full two‑month run).

fullContent:
Check Out Seoul’s New “Lonely‑Death” Pop‑Up – It’s a Must‑See. 

**

**
SUMMARY:

**  
Ever heard of a pop‑up that tackles lonely death.

In Seongsu‑dong, Seoul, a temporary shop is raising awareness, and it’s got a vibe you’ll love.

Find out how to hit it up, why it matters, and what it means for us Canadians. 

---

### CONTENT

**
Hook – The Canadian Connection**

title: Kakao Pay’s “Together for a Long Time” Pop‑Up in Seongsu: A Must‑See for Our Canadian Crew
summary: Hey, friends! Ever wondered what a Korean “popup” feels like? Let’s dive into Kakao Pay’s latest spot in Seongsu—think Toronto’s Kensington Market ...
fullContent:
Hey there, fellow wanderers! I’ve got a quick detour to share that’s going to make your next trip to Seoul feel a little more like home (or at least less like a textbook).

If you’re a fan of those spontaneous pop‑ups you see in Toronto’s Queen Street West or the quirky vibes of Kensington Market, you’ll want to know about Kakao Pay’s brand‑new “Together for a Long Time” popup that just opened up in Seongsu‑dong.

**What’s the deal?**
  
Kakao Pay is basically the Korean version of Apple Pay/Google Pay—just a mobile payment app that’s everywhere.

They’ve teamed up with a local café chain called Torotoro (yes, that’s the one that makes those fancy latte art “korean‑style” coffee drinks that are as Instagram‑ready as a double‑double in a Tim‑Hortons).

The popup is a temporary joint venture that blends the convenience of Kakao Pay with the cozy, indie café atmosphere of Seongsu.

Think of it as a cross between a tech expo and a pop‑up coffee shop.

**Where & When?**
  
- 

**Location:**
 3‑1 Seongdong‑ro, Seongsu‑dong, Seong‑dong‑gu, Seoul (just a few stops from the Seongsu Station on Line 2—easy to hop on a train from any part of the city).  
- 

**Hours:**
 10 AM – 10 PM (Mon‑Sat).

Closed on Sundays.  
- 

**Duration:**
 The popup is a 3‑month run (late April to early July), so you’ve got plenty of time to swing by if you’re in town.

**Cost & Currency**
  
- Entry is free—just walk in and you’re good to go.  
- Coffee & snacks: Standard menu items range from 4,000 KRW to 6,000 KRW.

That’s about $5–$7 CAD (exchange rates vary, but that’s a ballpark).  
- If you’re looking to try the “Kakao Pay only” specials (they’re basically a discount if you pay with the app), you’ll get about a 10–15% saving.

So, roughly $4–$6 CAD for a latte.

**Why should we care?**
  
1. 

**Tech + Culture Fusion:**
 For us Canadians who love tech, this is like seeing a Canadian startup show up in a pop‑up store in Toronto’s Distillery District.

You get to test out Kakao Pay’s features (like QR payments, in‑app ordering) in a real‑world setting—plus, you can see how the app integrates with Korean cafés.  
2. 

**Local Food & Coffee:**
 Torotoro’s coffee is seriously good.

Their “Mochi Latte” (a frothy, sweet treat) is a must‑try.

And the pastries—think butter croissants with a hint of matcha—are a sweet, buttery nod to our own Canadian bakery culture.  
3. 

**Community Vibe:**
 The popup is all about “togetherness.” They’ve set up a small communal table where you can meet other travelers, exchange travel hacks, or just chat over a latte.

It’s a great spot to meet fellow Canadians (and other expats) who might be in Seoul for the same reasons you are—study, work, or just exploring.

**Insider Tips**
  
- 

**Get There Early:**
 The first week after opening is the busiest—lines can be long, especially for the limited‑edition coffee.

Arrive around 10 AM or 2 PM to beat the crowds.  
- 

**Use Kakao Pay:**
 If you’re not already a Kakao Pay user, download the app and link it to your Korean bank account (or a local credit card).

You’ll get a small welcome discount that’s worth the extra step.  
- 

**Bring a Friend:**
 The popup offers a “group discount” if you’re buying for a small group (3 or more people).

It’s a fun way to share the experience and save a bit.  
- 

**Check Out the Art Installations:**
 They’ve got a rotating art gallery featuring local artists.

It’s a cool

title: Yo, Saskatoon! Snow Man’s Pop‑Up in Seongsu is the New‑Year’s Eve for K‑pop Fans—Let’s Dive In!
summary: Snow Man’s pop‑up launch in Seongsu is the must‑visit event for Canadian travelers. From the best cafés to insider merch tips, here’s everything yo...
fullContent:
Hey there, fellow Canadian wanderers! If you’re planning a trip to Seoul or already living in the city, you’ve probably heard the buzz: Snow Man’s pop‑up launch is happening in Seongsu, and it’s the hottest temporary spot for K‑pop fans right now.

I’m talking about the group’s newest album drop, exclusive merch, and a chance to rub elbows with Fukazawa Tatsuya himself.

Trust me, this is the kind of event that makes you want to grab a double‑double and tell your friends back home you’re living the dream.

### What’s the Deal?

Snow Man is a Japanese boy band that’s been making waves in Korea (yes, they’re that “Johnny & Associates” type).

Their latest single “Seong‑Seong” just dropped, and they’re celebrating with a pop‑up shop and live‑streamed performances in Seongsu‑dong, the “Brooklyn of Seoul.” The launch runs 

**Friday, April 12th to Sunday, April 14th**
, from 

**10 AM to 9 PM**
 each day.

The venue is the renovated warehouse at 

**Seongsu 701**
 (a popular indie hub that’s a stone’s throw from Seongsu Station).

### Where to Go and How to Get There

- 

**Address:**
 701 Seongsu‑dong, Seongdong‑gu, Seoul  
- 

**Transit:**
 Take Line 2 (the green line) to Seongsu Station.

Exit 2 and it’s a 5‑minute walk.

If you’re staying in Hongdae, it’s a quick 15‑minute subway ride.  
- 

**Parking:**
 Not much street parking, so use the underground lot at Seongsu 701 (about 50 KRW/parking minute, roughly $0.30 CAD).  

### What’s Inside?

1. 

**Merch Corner**
 – Think limited‑edition tees, enamel pins, and a “Snow Man” hoodie that’s a steal at 25,000 KRW (~$35 CAD).  
2. 

**Food & Drink**
 – The pop‑up has a mini‑café featuring Korean‑style latte art, and you can grab a “Seongsu‑style” donut (about 4,000 KRW or $5 CAD).  
3. 

**Live Performance**
 – Tatsuya and the crew will perform “Seong‑Seong” live on a small stage.

The set is 45 minutes, and the whole show is free (no ticket needed).  
4. 

**Fan Interaction**
 – A photo booth with a backdrop of Seongsu’s graffiti wall.

You can get your selfie taken with a snow‑man prop, and it’s a perfect Instagram moment.

### Insider Tips: What Locals Know

- 

**Arrive Early:**
 The first 100 visitors get a free “Se

title: House No Where in Seongsu – The “Art‑store” That’s a Must‑See for Every Canadian in Seoul
summary: Ever wondered what a 6‑ix‑style art gallery looks like in Seoul? Gentle Monster’s House No Where in Seongsu is a quirky, trend‑setting spot that fe...
fullContent:
Hey there, fellow Canucks! 👋

If you’re like me, you’ve spent a few months (or even a whole year) living in Seoul, scrolling through Instagram and seeing all the buzz about “hot spots” that are basically art‑filled storefronts.

One place that’s been getting a lot of chatter lately is 

**Gentle Monster’s House No Where**
 in Seongsu.

If you’re a Toronto or Vancouver student studying abroad, a Montreal foodie on a spring break, or just a curious friend, this is the kind of place that feels like a home‑grown version of the art scene back home, but with a Korean twist.

### What’s the Big Deal?

Gentle Monster started as a trendy eyewear brand, but they’ve turned the concept of a shop on its head.

House No Where isn’t just a place to buy glasses; it’s a rotating art space that blends architecture, fashion, and interactive installations.

Think of it as a pop‑up museum that changes every few months, and it’s all housed in a former factory space in Seongsu, which is Seoul’s answer to Toronto’s Distillery District or Vancouver’s Gastown.

The vibe is low‑key yet edgy—perfect for the “just‑got‑here‑and‑looking‑for‑something‑cool” kind of day.

### Practical Info: Where, When, and How Much

- 

**Location:**
 100 Seongsu‑dong, Seongdong‑gu, Seoul (you can get there via Subway Line 2 or 3, Exit 5; it’s about a 15‑minute walk from Seongsu Station).
- 

**Opening Hours:**
 11:00 am – 9:00 pm (last entry at 8:30 pm).

The space is open all week, but weekends are usually busier.
- 

**Admission:**
 Free! (Some special exhibitions or workshops may charge a small fee—usually around 5,000 KRW, which is roughly $5 CAD.

Keep an eye on the website for any extra costs.)
- 

**Parking:**
 Not much street parking, so public transit is your best bet.

If you’re driving from the airport, you’ll need a car‑sharing service or a taxi—budget about $20–$30 CAD for a one‑way ride from Incheon Airport.
- 

**What to Bring:**
 A camera (the installations are Instagram‑worthy), a reusable water bottle (they have a small café inside that serves coffee for about 2,000 KRW, roughly $2 CAD), and a comfy pair of shoes—Seongsu’s streets can be a bit uneven.

### Insider Tips: What Locals Know

1. 

**Timing is Key:**
 The first two hours after opening are the best for a quiet walk-through.

The crowds start to swell around 2 pm, especially on weekends.

If you’re into photography, early morning light is golden.
2. 

**Check the Schedule:**
 Gentle Monster posts their upcoming exhibitions on Instagram and their website.

They often collaborate with local artists and even international designers.

If you’re a fan of the Toronto

Art Gallery or the Vancouver

Art Gallery, you’ll recognize the level of curation here.
3. 

**Explore the Neighborhood:**
 Seongsu is home to a bunch of indie cafés, vintage shops, and the famous Seongsu‑dong bike

title: Gangnam‑Guu Sports Bash? You’re Gonna Love This, eh!
summary:
Hey fam! If you’re still wondering what’s happening in Seoul that’s not just K‑pop, Netflix, or a good cup of coffee, I’ve got a gem for you. Ever heard of the “Gangnam‑gu Developmental Disabilities Special Sports Event”? No? Well, it’s basically a city‑wide festival that’s happening this month in the heart of Gangnam, and it’s as heart‑warming as a double‑double at Tim Bennett’s. Grab your toque (or your hoodie if you’re a true Toronto winter‑survivor) and let’s dive in.

---

### Hook:  
Picture this: you’re strolling down the neon‑lit streets of Gangnam, the same spot where you’d spot a group of friends from UBC or the University of Calgary hanging out at a pop‑up café. Suddenly, a parade of people in bright, colorful outfits starts moving—some with wheelchairs, some with braces, all cheering, all laughing. That’s the vibe of this event. It’s a celebration of sport, inclusion, and community, and it’s happening right in your neighborhood (or at least within a short KTX ride from Vancouver).

---

### Context:  
Seoul’s city government is putting a spotlight on people with developmental disabilities, and they’re doing it through sports. Think of it like a mini‑Olympics, but with a focus on accessibility, fun, and community. It’s a temporary event, running from **July 15‑17** (yes, the same week we’re all hoping for a Canadian summer—maybe you’re at a beach in Halifax or a festival in Edmonton). The event is part of a larger city festival, so you’ll also get to see street performances, local food stalls, and maybe a K‑drama shoot (if you’re lucky).

Why should we Canadians care? Because it’s a perfect example of how cities can become more inclusive—something we’re all passionate about back home. If you’re a student at a Canadian university studying Korean culture, this is the real‑life classroom you can’t miss. And if you’re a tourist or a long‑term expat, it’s a chance to connect with locals and learn about a side of Seoul that’s often overlooked.

---

### Details:  
- **Where:**  
  *Main venue:* **Gangnam Sports Complex** (near **Seonjeongneung Station**, Line 2).  
  *Secondary spots:* **Coex Mall** (for food stalls) and **Sinsa-dong** (for street art).  

- **When:**  
  *Dates:* July 15‑17  
  *Times:* 10:00 AM – 10:00 PM each day (most activities start around noon).  

- **Cost:**  
  *Admission:* Free! (The city covers the cost, so you can just show up with your camera).  
  *Food & drinks:* Expect to spend about **$10‑$15 CAD** for a quick snack (think Korean fried chicken or a bento).  
  *Transportation:* A single **T-money** card for Seoul’s metro costs roughly **$1.50 CAD** per ride. If you’re coming from Toronto, a round‑trip flight to Seoul is about **$1,200‑$1,400 CAD** (depending on the season).  

- **What to bring:**  
  *Comfortable shoes (you’ll be walking a lot).  
  *A small water bottle (hydration is key).  
  *Your phone with a translation app (Google Translate or Papago).  
  *A camera or your phone for those Insta‑worthy moments.  

---

### Insider Tips:  

1. **Arrive early for the “Opening Ceremony.”**  
   The first day starts with a parade of athletes and a speech by the mayor. It’s a great way to get the energy and see the crowd before the main events.  

2. **Try the “Accessible Parkour.”**  
   This isn’t your typical parkour; it’s designed for people with varying abilities. The instructors are friendly and will show you a few basic moves. Even if you’re just a spectator, the enthusiasm is contagious.  

3. **Food hack:**  
   Grab a “Korean BBQ lunchbox” (a.k.a. **gopchang** or **bulgogi** meal) at **Coex Mall**. It’s about **$12 CAD** and you’ll get a full meal, plus you can share with new friends.  

4. **Meet the volunteers.**  
   They’re usually students from Korean universities who love community work. Strike up a conversation—they’ll tell you about other events in Seoul and maybe even invite you to a local “korean BBQ night” (a must‑try if you’re into food).  

5. **Use the “Seoul Pass” if you’re planning more than one day.**  
   It’s a multi‑day pass that gives you unlimited metro rides and discounts at many attractions. It

Hey there, eh! If you’re a Canadian who’s ever dreamed of sipping a mango‑flavoured ice‑cream while standing in a Seoul alley that looks like it could belong in Toronto’s Kensington Market, you’re in for a treat.

Baskin‑Robbins has launched a brand‑new pop‑up called the 

**Mango Bingo Gacha Shop**
 in the hip neighbourhood of 

**Seongsu‑dong**
.

Trust me, it’s as exciting as a surprise “loonie” in your wallet and just as sweet.

### # Where & When

- 

**Location:**
 12‑14 Seongsu‑dong 15‑ga, Seoul – right next to the Seongsu‑dong Station (Line 2).

It’s a stone’s throw from the Seongsu‑dong “Brooklyn” vibe: indie cafés, bike lanes, and a wall of murals that would make the Toronto

Distillery District jealous.
- 

**Hours:**
 10 AM – 9 PM (daily).

They’re open every day, but the best time to snag a freebie is early afternoon (12‑2 PM) when the crowds thin out.
- 

**Duration:**
 This is a temporary pop‑up – they’ll be there for about six weeks, so grab it while you can.

### # What’s the Gacha About?

It’s a stone’s throw from the Seongsu‑dong “Brooklyn” vibe: indie cafés, bike lanes, and a wall of murals that would make the Toronto

Distillery District jealous.
- 

**Hours:**
 10 AM – 9 PM (daily).

They’re open every day, but the best time to snag a freebie is early afternoon (12‑2 PM) when the crowds thin out.
- 

**Duration:**
 This is a temporary pop‑up – they’ll be there for about six weeks, so grab it while you can.

### # What’s the Gacha About?

fr.title: Salut les canadiens! Quelque chose d'incroyable se passe à Séoul en Corée. Cette expérience authentique est parfaite pour les canadiens qui visitent ou étudient en Corée.
fr.summary: Hey, fellow Canucks! Baskin‑Robbins just opened a mango‑themed gacha pop‑up in Seongsu‑dong. It’s a quick, tasty detour that feels oddly familiar—t...
fr.fullContent:
Salut les amis! If you’re a canadien who’s ever dreamed of sipping a mango‑flavoured ice‑cream while standing in a Séoul alley that looks like it could belong in Toronto’s Kensington Market, you’re in for a treat.

Baskin‑Robbins has launched a brand‑new pop‑up called the 

**Mango Bingo Gacha Shop**
 in the hip neighbourhood of 

**Seongsu‑dong**
.

Trust me, it’s as exciting as a surprise “loonie” in your wallet and just as sweet.

### # Where & When

- 

**Location:**
 12‑14 Seongsu‑dong 15‑ga, Séoul – right next to the Seongsu‑dong Station (Line 2).

It’s a stone’s throw from the Seongsu‑dong “Brooklyn” vibe: indie cafés, bike lanes, and a wall of murals that would make the Toronto

Distillery District jealous.
- 

**Hours:**
 10 AM – 9 PM (daily).

They’re open every day, but the best time to snag a freebie is early afternoon (12‑2 PM) when the crowds thin out.
- 

**Duration:**
 This is a temporary pop‑up – they’ll be there for about six weeks, so grab it while you can.
